I am a psychodynamic practitioner. The vast majority of my patients are low income and work with me through Medicaid.

Yes, psychoanalytic treatment is long-term and the underlying belief for most clinicians is basically that you get out what you put in... This might not comply with the quick-fix mentality of the mainstream, but it seems to hold true for most endeavors nonetheless.

I fully sympathize with the frustration being expressed here, but I can't help but feel it's misplaced. If the opportunity for this kind of treatment is as inaccessible as this person claims, surely this bespeaks of the need for a fundamental questioning of the mental health system as it stands, not an attack on a profession that is struggling (against massive odds) to find a place in our culture for the value of human experience.

At the same time, I believe that the Obama Administration-- with the strong exception of Joe Biden-- has been ineffectual at working with Congress and has done a notably poor job at rallying the Democratic base on behalf of Congressional Democrats.

My family turned our vacation home of 40 years into a rental property (when not in use by us) but we use a different vacation rental site, not AirBnB. The best thing we ever did was turn it into an LLC before we started renting. Yes. I believe your board may have a basis for suing to evict this owner. Keep in mind that coop owners in NYC don't really "own" their apartments. They own shares in the coop, which grants them a lease on the apt. Some violations can result in their being evicted from their apartments, even though they still own stock in the coop. It's extreme, and I'm sure hiring a lawyer to pursue such an action will cost the coop money, but it seems like it's worth looking into, given the repeated failure of this "owner" to respond to requests that he/she abide by the rules. Keep in mind you have more to worry about than a simple case of an AirBnB guest being injured. A guest could start a fire that seriously damages your building. Would your insurance cover that? Would AirBnb's?

Anetliner.....Is it a chicken and egg problem? If candidates don't give voters real choices to realize their wishes, then we get lowered turnout. Voters become discouraged and apathetic, so our politics doesn't respond, so lower turnout...

It leaves responding to a few intense protesters who rise up at gross violations of human rights. Otherwise we drift in a post democracy USA. Most Americans wouldn't be caught dead protesting in the streets.

It's easy to scold voters, but it goes deeper. In other democracies voter turnout is much higher--they have multi parties with explicit platforms and elections paid for by taxes, with free media time for candidates. This adds up to a system motivating citizens to vote. They see direct results from their choices. Our system combines to motivate the opposite.

We hope the protesters vote in 2016 for candidates who will create the change we need? But they are protesting just because we lack the mechanisms for political change.

Where will responsive candidates come from, how will they get financing? How will they fit in to the political culture of the 2 parties who try to subsume all views under their big tent, distorting the wishes of the majority?

States get away with various human rights violations that have no place in a democracy. Police abuse, voter rights interference, no health care.
So just urging us to vote in a rigged system is like holding up a match stick against a tidal wave. Or something.

Charles Blow addresses a critical issue in this column.

The events that have driven Americans into the streets must ultimately be addressed through the political system if there is to be lasting change. I applaud the demonstrations about the inequitable standard of justice displayed in the Garver case and supported the messages of the Occupy and climate change demonstrations.

But none of this is worth a damn if people don't go out and vote on their convictions. It's hard to take activism seriously if it doesn't translate into results at the ballot box. I hope that the protesters will honor their causes by nominating and voting in 2016 for local, state and federal candidates who will support their views and create the change they desire.

There are two ways to discourage the abuse of customer data:

1) Regulation. To my mind, companies should be prohibited from making customer data public and from selling customer data (with the exception of anonymous aggregate data) without the customer's signed consent. (No, a clause buried in the service agreement is insufficient. I'd like to see federal action on this front.

2) The market. If consumers are upset, they can stop using Uber and Facebook. Thus far, there is little evidence that this is taking place.

Yes, and had Lincoln "moved immediately" to call for abolition at the beginning of his return to politics, he never could have become a candidate for senate in 1858, nor a candidate for president in 1860. Lincoln was a politician trying to win elections, not a pamphleteer trying to sell pamphlets.

In 1876 Douglass delivered a speech in which he gave his considered opinion of Lincoln on the issue of emancipation.  He was critical of the president, but  near the end of the speech, he stated, "Viewed from the genuine abolition ground, Mr. Lincoln was tardy, cold, dull and indifferent; but measuring him by the sentiment of his country,  a sentiment he was bound as a statesman to consult, he was swift, zealous, radical and determined."   Douglass acknowledged that, had the president moved immediately to abolish slavery at the beginning of the war, he would have lost the support necessary to save the union and to end slavery.  This speech   has long seemed to me a fair and accurate assessment of Abraham Lincoln as emancipator.

"H)ow and why did professional philosophy become so seemingly unconcerned with the questions about self-knowledge which non-philosophers find interesting?"

Academic philosophy is an intellectual pursuit that isolates its practitioners from the necessarily unobstructed knowledge of the absolute. The academic presumption of an invariant primordial structure - the foundation of arithmetic, the foundation of geometry, time, e.g. - allows an individual to presume proximity to absolute knowledge is facilitated through intellectual prowess.

The philosophy of self-knowledge has become "narrow in scope" by virtue of the valorization of specificity: the presumption that there is an external invariant to be pursued and knowledge thereof may only be realized and articulated through precision; wisdom as an artifact of intellect.

Academic philosophy has a "bad name" because knowledge of the absolute, primordial knowledge, is necessarily unobstructed. Those incapable of articulating such knowledge are no less informed by said knowledge than the most articulate of academics. By the same token, although perhaps incapable of explaining why, the inarticulate, informed as they are, are well aware that the illusions of artificial structure and specificity are never more than the conceits of self-absorption.

"(T)echnical solutions to technical problems" are likewise artifacts of the valorization of specificity; artificial invariants employed to determine the nature of their reflection.
